article.headline: Michigan 88, Hawaii 73
article.story: ANN ARBOR, Mich. (AP) -- Michigan is taking advantage of its second chance. Lester Abram scored 17 points to lead five players in double figures and the Wolverines beat Hawaii 88-73 Wednesday night in the quarterfinals of the NIT. Michigan (21-11), in the postseason for the first time since the 2000 NIT after winning an appeal of a tournament ban last fall, advanced to next week's semifinals in New York. The Wolverines will play the winner of Thursday's Oregon-Notre Dame game. "It's definitely not a lost season now," said senior Bernard Robinson, who had 14 points and seven assists in his final game at Crisler Arena. "We have to savor this moment because we've had one of the best seasons around here in years." The last time Michigan won more than 20 games was 1997-98, one of the seasons the school forfeited all its victories from as part of its self-imposed sanctions stemming from its involvement with now-deceased booster Ed Martin. The 1997 NIT championship banner -- along with two NCAA Final Four banners from the Fab Five era -- also were taken down by the school. Coach Tommy Amaker said the Wolverines were fortunate to have a chance to play in the postseason. "It was a really special night for us to be able to advance to New York City," Amaker said. "It's been a blessing for us to be in this tournament because we've found something within in our team, and the fan support has been phenomenal." Crisler Arena often has been a dull place for Michigan to play basketball, but it has been raucous during the NIT. More than 10,000 fans were rowdy Wednesday night, before the game even started. The Wolverines also won the NIT in 1984, the season before they won two straight Big Ten titles, the last conference championships in team history. Michigan's Graham Brown tied a career high with 14 points, Daniel Horton had 13 points and five assists and Dion Harris added 12 points. Abram came off the bench and was effective after missing the previous three games with a left shoulder injury. "I didn't realize he led us in scoring," Amaker said. "To play the way he did after the long layoff says a lot about the kid's toughness." The Rainbow Warriors (21-12) have made it to the NIT quarterfinals five times, and have lost each game. Hawaii's Michael Kuebler scored 19, Julian Sensley had 16 points and five assists and Haim Shimonovich added 12 points and eight rebounds. "I think mentally, we were fatigued," Sensley said. Hawaii made quite a turnaround to travel to its first game in Michigan. The Warriors beat Nebraska at home late Monday night, traveled to Salt Lake City where they had a layover and arrived in Michigan late Wednesday afternoon. Hawaii looked tired midway through the second half, and the Wolverines turned it into a rout. "I thought we were at about 75 percent," Hawaii coach Riley Wallace said. "We asked them to do the impossible." After five ties and two lead changes early in the game, Michigan built a nine-point lead. The Rainbows came back and tied the game three times before trailing 43-37 at halftime. Horton scored six points during the first four minutes of the second half to give the Wolverines a 53-43 lead, and the Warriors didn't get closer than seven thereafter.
